channel.title: Bloomberg Markets

item.title: Asian Stocks Set to Advance as US Inflation Cools: Markets Wrap
item.description: Asian equity-index futures were buoyed by gains in stocks and bonds on Wall Street as further signs of cooling US inflation prepared investors for Federal Reserve rate cuts.
item.dc:creator: Richard Henderson

item.title: Warner Bros. Is Close to Winning Support for Debt Overhaul
item.description: Warner Bros. Discovery Inc. is close to winning support from creditors to overhaul its debt, a key part of a broader reorganization plan that would split the entertainment firm in two separate companies.
item.dc:creator: Reshmi Basu

media:content.media:description: Signage at the Warner Bros. Discovery headquarters in New York, US, on Thursday, June 12, 2025. Warner Bros. Discovery Inc. is splitting itself in half, unshackling its fast-growing streaming business from the struggling legacy media channels and setting up two independent companies that could pursue deals on their own. Photographer: Victor J. Blue/Bloomberg

item.title: Fintech Chime Climbs 37% in Debut After $864 Million IPO
item.description: Chime Financial Inc. rose 37% in its trading debut after pricing its shares above the marketed range to raise raising $864 million in the year’s sixth-biggest US initial public offering.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Hughes, Paige Smith, Katie Roof

media:content.media:description: Attendees celebrate during the Chime Financial Inc. initial public offering at the Nasdaq MarketSite in New York, US, on Thursday, June 12, 2025. Chime Financial Inc. shares are indicated to open at $45 each on Thursday, as much as 67% above the initial public offering price of $27 each.

item.title: Why Long Bonds Are Falling Out of Favor
item.description: Jamie Dimon drew varied reactions with his prediction that the bond market is going to “crack” if the US government doesn’t get a grip on a ballooning federal deficit.
item.dc:creator: Greg Ritchie, Liz Capo McCormick, Mia Glass

media:content.media:description: A Wall Street sign near the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Monday, April 21, 2025. US stocks tumbled as President Donald Trump continued to verbally attack Jerome Powell, calling on the Federal Reserve chair to cut rates as signs mount the president's trade war is pushing the economy toward recession. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

item.title: California Regulator Probing State Farm Over Claims Processes
item.description: California’s insurance regulator has launched a formal investigation into State Farm’s handling of claims related to January’s Los Angeles wildfires, after groups of survivors complained that the process could lead to confusion and delayed payouts.
item.dc:creator: Alexandre Rajbhandari

media:content.media:description: ALTADENA, CALIFORNIA - MAY 22: In an aerial view, properties burned in the Eaton Fire are shown cleared of wildfire debris on May 22, 2025 in Altadena, California. The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers announced it has cleared 5,000 properties in the Eaton and Palisades fires burn zones, which represents half of the eligible properties, in just three months. (Photo by Mario Tama/Getty Images)

item.title: ‘I Got Up and Ran’: How One Man Survived the Plane Crash That Killed 241
item.description: As Air India Flight AI171 descended toward its doom on Thursday, Ramesh Vishwaskumar sat in the first row of economy class — headed for one of the most harrowing and luckiest moments of his life.
item.dc:creator: Benedikt Kammel

media:content.media:description: Aircraft debris at the crash site of Air India Ltd. flight AI171 in Ahmedabad, Gujarat, India, on Thursday, June 12, 2025. An Air India Boeing 787 Dreamliner traveling from Ahmedabad to London’s Gatwick airport crashed shortly after taking off, in what stands to be the most serious accident involving the US planemaker's most advanced widebody airliner.

item.title: BPCE Is Nearing an Almost €7 Billion Deal for Novo Banco
item.description: Lone Star Funds has decided to pursue a sale of Portuguese lender Novo Banco SA and has entered into exclusive discussions with French banking group BPCE, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Kirchfeld, Swetha Gopinath, Dinesh Nair, Henrique Almeida

media:content.media:description: A Novo Banco SA bank branch in Lisbon, Portugal, on Monday, June 9, 2025. Lone Star’s Portuguese lender Novo Banco attracted two bids from French banking group BPCE and CaixaBank SA of Spain, according to people familiar with the matter.

item.title: S&P 500 Rises as Ebbing Inflation Sends Bond Yields Lower
item.description: The S&P 500 Index eked out gains for the fourth day in five sessions on Thursday, with traders welcoming another cooling inflation print while reacting little to the latest round of US-China trade talks.
item.dc:creator: Jess Menton

media:content.media:description: An S&P 500 SPX chart on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Thursday, April 17, 2025. US stocks traded steady, reversing gains from earlier in the day, as Wall Street traders weighed the latest earnings results and the impact of President Donald Trump’s tariffs on Corporate America. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

item.title: US 30-Year Bond Sale Spurs ‘Sigh of Relief’ After Weeks of Angst
item.description: A closely watched auction of 30-year Treasuries saw stronger-than-expected demand on Thursday, easing for now worries that investors would shun the US government’s longest maturity.
item.dc:creator: Michael Mackenzie

media:content.media:description: The US Treasury building in Washington, DC, US, on Tuesday, Dec. 31, 2024. The US Treasury Department was hacked by a Chinese state-sponsored actor through a third-party software service provider, according to a letter the agency sent to Congress on Monday. Photographer: Samuel Corum/Bloomberg

item.title: Early Chime Investor on the IPO’s Timing
item.description: Menlo Ventures Partner Shawn Carolan, an early investor in Chime, says the company’s mission and focus on customers' actual needs is what helped the company reach its IPO. Carolan joins Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow on “Bloomberg Tech.” (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Stocks Finish Higher on Thin Volume | Closing Bell
item.description: Comprehensive cross-platform coverage of the U.S. market close on Bloomberg Television, Bloomberg Radio, and YouTube with Romaine Bostick, Alix Steel, Scarlet Fu, Carol Massar and Tim Stenovec. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Bond Rally Gains Steam on Strong $22 Billion Sale: Markets Wrap
item.description: A solid sale of long-term Treasuries reduced fears that spiraling deficits are causing investors to shun the bonds, with the market also gaining as soft inflation fueled bets the Federal Reserve will cut rates should the economy decelerate. The dollar hit a three-year low. Stocks rose.
item.dc:creator: Rita Nazareth

media:content.media:description: DoubleLine Group CEO Jeffrey Gundlach talks about the price of gold, fixed income, private credit, President Donald Trump's tax bill, Federal Reserve monetary policy and artificial intelligence with Lisa Abramowicz at the Bloomberg Global Credit Forum in Los Angeles.

item.title: Dollar Falls to Lowest Since 2022 as Economic Outlook Dims
item.description: The dollar fell to the weakest level in three years amid worries over US tariffs and the outlook for the US economy.
item.dc:creator: Anya Andrianova, Vassilis Karamanis

item.title: Gold Advances on Fed Rate-Cut Bets and Middle East Tensions
item.description: Gold rose after another soft inflation report bolstered bets that the Federal Reserve may need to cut interest rates later this year.
item.dc:creator: Yvonne Yue Li, Jack Ryan

media:content.media:description: Gold bars at the Italpreziosi SpA precious metals refinery plant arranged in Arezzo, Italy, on Tuesday, May 6, 2025. Gold fell, snapping a two-day advance, as signs of progress on US-China trade talks curbed demand for havens even as military hostilities between India and Pakistan escalated. Photographer: Alessia Pierdomenico/Bloomberg

item.title: Oracle Earnings and Chip Demand
item.description: Chime CEO Chris Britt says the company has multiple ways to grow and is focused on the long term. Britt speaks with Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow ahead of he company's IPO on “Bloomberg Tech.” (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Pimco Hires Advisers for Loan Tied to Saks-Neiman Marcus Deal
item.description: A Pacific Investment Management Co.-led group holding loans tied to the sale of Neiman Marcus Group has tapped advisers to help ensure they get repaid when the debt comes due next year.
item.dc:creator: Reshmi Basu, Eliza Ronalds-Hannon

media:content.media:description: A Neiman Marcus store in Garden City, New York, US, on Friday, July 5, 2024. The owner of Saks Fifth Avenue is acquiring Neiman Marcus Group for $2.65 billion, a deal that will unite America's two largest high-end department-store chains in a bid to grab a bigger share of a slowing industry. Photographer: Yuki Iwamura/Bloomberg

item.title: NRG CEO Coben Expects Data Center Deals All Over US
item.description: NRG Energy President and CEO Larry Coben says there's not enough electricity in the grid to power nuclear energy. Speaking on "Bloomberg The Close," Coben also discusses the company's LS Power deal and energy regulation. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Marelli Approved to Borrow $519 Million at Start of Bankruptcy
item.description: Bankrupt auto-parts supplier Marelli Holdings Co. won court approval to borrow $518.9 million to help fund its reorganization after delaying a request for some parts of a financing package questioned by a federal bankruptcy watchdog.
item.dc:creator: Steven Church

media:content.media:description: The Marelli Corp. headquarters in Saitama, Japan.

item.title: NYC May Face Annual Budget Gaps of $13 Billion, DiNapoli Says
item.description: New York City may be headed for annual deficits of as much as $13 billion because it under-budgets costs for social services and overtime, according to state Comptroller Thomas DiNapoli.
item.dc:creator: Martin Z Braun

media:content.media:description: A waterfront park across from One World Trade Center and lower Manhattan in Jersey City, New Jersey, US, on Thursday, June 20, 2024. These days more New Yorkers are trading coveted NYC zip codes for high-end finishes, extensive amenities and New Jersey’s slightly cheaper cost of living.

item.title: US Investigators to Help in Deadly Air India Crash
item.description: Investigators from the FAA and NTSB will help determine the cause of a deadly Air India jet crash. The Boeing 737 Dreamliner crashed shortly after takeoff in India. More than 200 bodies were recovered. The jet was powered by two General Electric engines. Ryan Beene reports. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Sunnova Secures $90 Million Lifeline to Support Bankruptcy Sale
item.description: Sunnova Energy International Inc. won court approval to start drawing on a new $90 million bankruptcy loan, funding that will help keep the rooftop solar company afloat while it sells its business in Chapter 11.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Randles

media:content.media:description: Workers install solar panels at a home in San Francisco.

item.title: Oil Steadies as Traders Weigh Tariff Threats Against Iran Risk
item.description: Oil held steady as traders weighed renewed tariff threats from the US against the potential for widespread conflict in the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: Mia Gindis, Alex Longley

item.title: Options Traders Bet on Pause in Dollar’s ‘Sell America’ Rout
item.description: The dollar is trading at a three-year low, but options traders are betting the frenzied selloff in the world’s reserve currency will peter out over the next few weeks.
item.dc:creator: George Lei

item.title: US Economy Has Been 'Relying on Kindness of Strangers' For 3 Years
item.description: Jayati Bharadwaj, FX and macro strategist at TD Securities, breaks down why the US Dollar has remained weak, even as other economic indicators are strong amid Trump's trade war. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Sen. Padilla Forcibly Removed From Noem News Conference
item.description: US Senator Alex Padilla was forcibly removed from a press conference, handcuffed, and detained after trying to confront Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem.

item.title: US Biofuel Makers Are Stuck in a Slump While Waiting for Trump Policy
item.description: The White House is gearing up to finally announce its new rules on biofuel blending, critical support for the industry that’s underpinned American farming over the past two decades. But for some producers of diesel made from soybeans, the move won’t be enough to rescue them from a months-long downturn that’s led to plant closings and layoffs.
item.dc:creator: Kim Chipman

media:content.media:description: A shovel sits next to spilled corn near a mill at the Poet Biorefining facility in Jewell, Iowa, U.S., on Wednesday, Feb. 21, 2018. Renewable Identification Numbers, used by oil refiners and regulators to record compliance of biofuel rules, tracking 2018 ethanol consumption quotas fell 6.1 percent, according to broker data. President Trump and his officials are said to be holding summits to discuss possible changes to the mandate.

item.title: Private Equity Stuck in Limbo Gets Help From Direct Lenders
item.description: As private equity firms struggle to sell the companies they own and return cash to investors, their counterparts in the world of private credit are offering special loans to tide them over.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Schneider, Olivia Fishlow

item.title: Penn Secures $500 Million in Lines of Credit After Trump Funding Risk
item.description: The trustees of the University of Pennsylvania have landed lines of credit totaling $500 million as Ivy League schools continue to face federal funding pressures from the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Albright, Elizabeth Rembert

media:content.media:description: The College Hall on the University of Pennsylvania campus in Philadelphia on Friday, Dec. 8, 2023.

item.title: Chime CEO Talks Growth As the Fintech Goes Public
item.description: Chime CEO Chris Britt says the company has multiple ways to grow and is focused on the long term. Britt speaks with Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow ahead of he company's IPO on “Bloomberg Tech.” (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Easing US Capital Rules Will Cut Treasury Yields, Eurizon’s Jen Says
item.description: Relaxing the US government’s capital requirements for banks using the supplementary leverage ratio will likely free up cash and lead to lower Treasury yields, according to Eurizon SLJ Capital.
item.dc:creator: Carter Johnson

media:content.media:description: The US Treasury building in Washington, DC, US, on Saturday, June 3, 2023. The Senate last week passed legislation to suspend the US debt ceiling through the 2024 election, ending a drama that threatened a global financial crisis ahead of the Treasury secretary's June 5 deadline to avoid a default.
